item.title: Want a challenge? Help me
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

This is another one of those “I don’t know how to solve it so it must be the hardest challenge in the world” threads.

Set proper Java Environmental Variables, or use what the web guy said.

if the main class can’t be found, make sure your path to it is valid.
Same goes if it can’t find the path.
The other error is because of EV’s.

Read full topic

item.title: Want a challenge? Help me
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

[quote=“xXSh0ckXx, post:2, topic:543974”][quote author=morot4 link=topic=662856.msg4429991#msg4429991 date=1402800019]
So, me and my friend, wanting to host a source and fudge around with admin features, pk each other and stuff tried finding a working server source yesterday for over 6 hours. Every single time we downloaded and used a source, there would either be path finding errors “can’t find path” or “can’t find main class”, or “this is not an internal or external command” or 100 errors etc.

I made sure my Java Environmental Variables were set correct by watching thousands of tutorials. Anybody want a challenge?
If you can make it so i can run at least one source in downloads, i’ll give you two bucks or something over paypal and love you forever.
I got teamviewer, if you’d like to help me over that. I can also screenshare.

my skype is: emil1000123

Recently i tried hosting and running these clients and server:
BeastPk
Spawn-Scape
Deathlypvpz 4.0
Zaryte
Project-Exile
[/quote]
Pay4help is not allowed, please read the rules…[/quote]

Yeah, payments aren’t allowed man.

Anyways, don’t bother with setting up the environmental variables. If you edit your run.bat file with notepad or some other text editor, you’ll see “javac” somewhere, replace that with the location of your javac.exe. For example…

Replace this: (and only this, leave the rest of the line alone)

With this:

You may have to make some changes depending on what version of JDK you have. To figure it out go to C:/ > Program Files [or Program Files (x86) > Java > jdk#.#.#_##/ … And that’ll tell you what version you have. If you still can’t figure it out, add me on Skype and I’ll do it for you. But keep in mind, payments aren’t accepted on these forums. People here help solely out of kindness.

Read full topic
